instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the investigation of the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention?
Output: In the investigation of the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention, near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) was used.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the investigation of the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention?
Output: The investigation utilized both O2Hb and HHb variables as spectral feature processing methods to assess the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention.

instruction: What metric was chosen in the investigation of the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen in the related study was the classification accuracy, which measures the ability of the machine learning algorithm to correctly classify the two levels of attention (full attention and attention decrement) based on the NIRS-derived signal features. The related study found that the classification accuracy ranged from 65% to 90%. The highest classification accuracy was achieved when using the oxyhemoglobin signals, ranging from 77% to 89%, depending on the cortical area considered. The classification accuracy increased to 90% when using signals from the right parietal area rather than from the prefrontal cortex. Therefore, the chosen metric of classification accuracy was able to achieve relatively good results in distinguishing between different levels of attention.

instruction: How did the related study investigate the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention in conjunction with machine learning techniques?
Output: The related study investigated the reliability of optical measures of cortical correlates of attention in conjunction with machine learning techniques by conducting a sustained attention task with seven subjects. Near infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) monitoring was used to measure the NIRS signals from the prefrontal and right parietal areas of the subjects during the task. The NIRS signals from the first 10 minutes of the task were considered as characterizing the 'full attention' class, while the NIRS signals from the last 10 minutes of the task were considered as characterizing the 'attention decrement' class. A two-class support vector machine algorithm was then used to distinguish between the two levels of attention using appropriate NIRS-derived signal features. The classification accuracy of the algorithm was assessed to determine the reliability of the optical measures and machine learning techniques in tracking attention levels.

instruction: Can the spectral feature processing methods using NIRS signals be considered superior to traditional methods in distinguishing between states of full attention and states characterized by reduced attention capacity during a sustained attention task?
Output: Yes.Based on the information provided in the related study, the spectral feature processing methods using NIRS signals can be considered superior to traditional methods in distinguishing between states of full attention and states characterized by reduced attention capacity during a sustained attention task. The related study found that the classification accuracy ranged from 65% to 90%, with the highest accuracy achieved when using oxyhemoglobin signals and signals from the right parietal area. This suggests that the NIRS signals and machine learning techniques have the potential to accurately differentiate between different levels of attention during a sustained attention task.
